acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 72 hours EC50=100microg/L of the algae (Scenedesmus) (AQUIRE, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) of 48mg/kg (ATSDR (2003)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category D by EPA (1993) and Group 3 by IARC (1987).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on in vivo mutagenicity/genotoxicity tests and no positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro (several indices), described in ATSDR (2003) and EHC 58 (1986).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to the absence of data, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the reports of occupational exposure (PATTY (4th, 2000) and EHC 58 (1986)): "Selenium dioxide produced irritation of the eye, but the effects were reversible." The substance should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: A case of human occupational exposure is reported in EHC 58 (1986): "skin irritation was observed among workers handling selenium dioxide."  However, this effect might potentially be attributable to selenious acid which is generated when selenium dioxide comes in contact with water or perspiration. Given this, it was decided not to use this specific observation for classification.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, liver)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "moderate pulmonary emphysema and hepatic function disorder" (EHC 58 (1986)), and the evidence from animal studies including "acute renal failure and acute renal tubular necrosis" (RTECS (2004)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (heart, central nervous system, blood system),
Category 2 (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (heart, central nervous system, blood system)
May cause damage to organs (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "diffuse swelling of the heart and cerebral edema; most notable findings were orange-brown discoloration of skin and whole internal organs, which appears to be attributable to hemolysis" (PATTY (4th, 2000)) and "pulmonary edema" (HSDB (1998)), and the evidence from animal studies including "decreases in activity/muscle tension/contact response/breathing, low body temperature" (ATSDR (2004)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (nervous system).
